newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania appoints British ex-minister as adviser.
newsitem.headline: Romania appoints British ex-minister as adviser.

text.p: Romania has chosen British ex-Chancellor of the Exchequer Norman Lamont to help the Balkan country open an investment bank in Britain to attract foreign investors, officials said on Tuesday.

"Mr. Lamont will advise both the State Ownership Fund (FPS) and the Romanian Development Agency (ARD) on the opening of the bank," said Stefan Ciochinaru, spokesman for the FPS, which holds majority stakes in most state companies.
The bank would provide financial advisory services to foreign investors and Romanian companies, according to a statement from the Balli Group of Britain, headed by Lamont.
Balli, a commodities and financial services group, already has a presence in Romania in the aluminium sector.
The project is part of the centrist government's drive to step up reforms and recoup delays in privatisation, which stalled under the former leftist cabinet.
As chancellor in the early 1980s, Lamont played a key role in privatising British Telecom and British Airways.

Balli's statement said FPS President Sorin Dimitriu had talks with executives of leading banks Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan, Merrill Lynch, Schroders and Credit Suisse First Boston in London last week, "to discuss Romania's ambitious economic reform and privatisation programme".
